results.title: Flat
results.brief_description: Carried out in a 2D reality, repetitive motions mirror the mechanical patterns in modern society. In this one-shot abstracted sequence, abscuring motion and direction, repeated gestures move beyond meaning and into compulsive necessity. Detail magnifies while reason fades.
results.description: Carried out in a 2D reality, repetitive motions mirror the mechanical patterns in modern society. In this one-shot abstracted sequence, abscuring motion and direction, repeated gestures move beyond meaning and into compulsive necessity. Detail magnifies while reason fades.

results.title: Flashpoint
results.creator_credit: Ernie Schmidt, Don Worobey and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An animated interpretation of the Pacific Ocean ablaze as a result of a collision between two giant supertankers. The film explains that there is no technology available to cope with such a disaster, and in a realistic, animated way it is a reminder of the dangers of tanker traffic in coastal waters. The stunning animation method used in this short film is similar to Japanese ‘Manga’ style. Although this film deals with serious issues surrounding environmental disasters, it manages to introduce some comic moments that simultaneously educate and entertain. Story by Ian Slater. Animation by Ernie Schmidt.

results.title: Flemingdon Park: the global village
results.creator_credit: Andrew Faiz, Gerry Flahive and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A trendy urban development in Toronto for professionals and artists turned subsidized housing which attracted thousands of refugees and new immigrants, Flemingdon Park has become known as a multicultural model for urban planning. This documentary discusses the past and present community of Flemingdon Park, as well as the challenges the diverse residents face and the valuable lessons offered by the community that has developed there. From a history of overcoming violence and racism to the hope of the celebration of difference in increasingly inclusive and welcoming community attitudes there are many and varied facets to life in and around the Park. Many of these elements are touched on in this program in order to come to terms with the history and current experience of the community through interviews with past and present residents, teachers and students from neighbouring schools, the Park’s designer and architect and through commentary from journalist Robert Fulford and the documentary’s director, Andrew Faiz, himself a former resident.

results.title: Videoworks of Sadie Benning. Volume 3
results.brief_description: A collection of three remarkable works by Sadie Benning produced between 1995-1998 including German Song, The Judy Spots and Flat is Beautiful. Shot in black and white Super-8 film, Benning’s lyrical short muses on a disengaged youth and grey afternoons spent wandering, and features the hard-edged music of Come, an alternative band from Boston. “The Judy Spots” is a tape composed of five episodes featuring Judy, a teenage girl puppet made of papiermache as she plays in a band, works at a fast food restaurant, shops at the mall and feels scared at night. “Flat is Beautiful” is an experimental, live-action cartoon narrative using masks, animation, subtitles, drawings and dramatic scenes to investigate the psychic life of an androgynous eleven-year-old girl. Growing up in a working class neighborhood with her single mother and gay roommate, Taylor confronts the loneliness of living between masculine and feminine in a culture obsessed with defining gender difference. Shifting between black and white film and grainy pixelvision video, ‘Flat is Beautiful’ explores the internal and external worlds of sad people.

results.title: Flare: a ski trip
results.creator_credit: Sam Neill, Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: A team of six skiers returning to New Zealand demonstrate freestyle skiing. The three basic Freestyle skills; Ballet, Jumping and Moguls or Bumps are shown in North and South Island Skifields. The film culminates in a skier’s dream - to ski the untracked slopes of a live volcano.

results.title: Five Go to Smuggler's Top
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Famous Five”.
The Five go to Smuggler’s Top to stay with the Lenoir family. It is not long before they meet the eccentric Mr Barlowe - a man who seems to be responsible for the queer and highly suspicious things that are happening in the area. The five face a mystery full of excitement in and out of the underground secret passages and on the surrounding sea marshes. Rated: G

results.title: Five go down to the sea
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Famous Five”.
While on a cycling holiday in Cornwall, the Five hear how in the past, pirates used to set up a light on stormy nights on the Tremannon coast to wreck ships. The children investigate the cove at night and find that there are still mysterious lights and some sinister goings-on.

results.title: Five are together again. Parts 1 & 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Famous Five”.
With Quentin Kirrin and his wife in quarantine for scarlet fever, the children are sent to stay with Professor Hayling and his son, Tinker. An exciting adventure begins when a circus comes to town and some ‘top secret’ notes disappear from the Professor’s study.

results.title: Five run away together. Five have a wonderful time
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Famous Five”.
In “Five run away together”, the children run away from Kirrin Cottage, when the bad Mrs. Stick, who is looking after them for a week, threatens to lock Timmy in the shed. They escape to Kirrin Island, where all is not as it should be. “Five have a wonderful time” introduces us to a snake-charmer called Miss Slither, and a fire-eater called Alfredo. While on their caravanning holiday, the children find that they must enlist the help of these new friends when they uncover a mystery at nearby Faynight’s Castle.
